qas.question: Who was the Archbishop of Milan?
New pontiffs are chosen from Cardinals who head what?

answers.text: archdioceses or departments of the Roman Curia

qas.question: When was Montini absent from the conclave?
What was the Roman curia absent from in 1958?

plausible_answers.text: any Catholic male who is capable of receiving priestly ordination and episcopal consecration

qas.question: Who can be elected to the College of Cardinals under Canon Law?

plausible_answers.text: among the Cardinals who head archdioceses or departments of the Roman Curia that attend the papal conclave

qas.question: Where did the College of Cardinals choose the Archbishop of Milan from?
What age did the Archbishop of Milan not have to be below to serve in office?

plausible_answers.text: one of the most ancient and prominent sees

qas.question: What were Eastern-rite Cardinals in charge of in Italy?

context: Many had considered <a0_0>Giovanni Battista Montini<a0_0/>, the Archbishop of Milan, a possible candidate, but, although he was the archbishop of <b7_0>one of the most ancient and prominent sees<b7_0/> in Italy, he had not yet been made a cardinal. Though his absence from the <a2_0>1958<a2_0/> <b3_0>conclave<b3_0/> did not make him ineligible – under Canon Law <b4_0>any Catholic male who is capable of receiving priestly ordination and episcopal consecration<b4_0/> may be elected – the College of Cardinals usually chose the new pontiff from <b5_0>among the Cardinals who head <a1_0>archdioceses or departments of the Roman Curia<a1_0/> that attend the papal conclave<b5_0/>. At the time, as opposed to contemporary practice, the participating Cardinals did not have to be below <b6_0>age 80<b6_0/> to vote, there were few Eastern-rite Cardinals, and no Cardinals who were just priests at the time of their elevation.
